resources.string: FPV-VR for wifibroadcast

Advanced VR rendering technique, modified for FPV-VR. Lowest input lag possible (8.3ms), without any visual imperfections like tearing. Has high performance and hardware requirements, that are only fulfilled on high-end phones. I recommend a Daydream-ready device. If you enable this technique on non-daydream ready phones, you might see stuttering and/or tearing.

Disables VSYNC (Vertical Sync). Reduces input lag to ~16.6ms@120fps or less, depending on your hardware (higher fps->less latency). WARNING: Has the negative side effect of Tearing (Visual imperfections) and wasted frames It is up to you if you can live with tearing for a lower latency, but I definitely recommend enabling this option if available.

VSYNC on (no tearing), but >60 OpenGL fps (lower latency). Input lag is at ~33.2ms@120fps. WARNING: when your phone has trouble rendering at >60fps, enabling this option can increase latency. Also, disabling VSYNC gives much lower latency.

MSAA increases quality with very little performance loss. Which MSAA level to choose depends on your GPU power, screen resolution and magnification of your VR headset. Most modern tile-based GPUs can handle up to 4xMSAA with only 10-20perc. performance loss, while increasing quality significantly.
Set to zero when you do not want to have an 3D Effect;for each Person different, but a default value of 0.2 seems to be optimal
Connect via UDP (Network Protocol) to your WB FPV receiver (rpi). When you connected successfully, you can see counter(s) indicating how much data has been received.
Connect via UDP (Network Protocol) to any FPV receiver. Since UDP is unidirectional the app can only check if data arrives at the specified UDP ports.
Play a test video/telemetry file (included in the app) to test your decoder
Play video/telemetry from files in your internal storage (Ground Recording).

You can find your ground recording files in "DCIM\FPV_VR". 
To sync files with windows, connect your phone as "camera device". 
Enter your file names (e.g. 11-04-2019 16-33-42 are creation date and time) 
They have to be in the right format and sit in your FPV_VR folder
In development. Enter valid RTSP string (or other string that can be played by ffmpeg), then start video playing activity.
DJI In development.
Mode 1: Connect to EZ-WB/OpenHD RX Pi via Wifi
Mode 2: Connect to EZ-WB/OpenHD RX Pi via USB cable

Connect your mobile phone to EZ-WB/OpenHD RX Pi via Wifi 
1)On your RX PI (wifibroadcast-1 file): WIFI_HOTSPOT=Y; VIDEO_UDP_PORT=5600; 
 Start RX and TX PIs 
2)On your Phone: Activate Wifi and connect to "EZ-WifiBroadcast" using "wifibroadcast" as passphrase 
 Or "OpenHD" using "wifiopenhd" as passphrase 
3)If your RX Pi also has a display connected: Wait for "Secondary Display Connected" message to appear on your RX Pi Monitor

Connect your Mobile Phone to EZ-WB/OpenHD RX Pi via USB cable 
1)On your RX PI (wifibroadcast-1 file): VIDEO_UDP_PORT=5600; 
 Start RX and TX PIs 
2)Connect your Phone to the RX Pi via USB Cable 
3)On your Phone: Enable "USB tethering" (now the Phone acts as Hotspot via USB and the RPI automatically connects) 
4)If your RX Pi also has a display connected: Wait for "Secondary Display Connected" Message to appear on your RX Pi Monitor

Connect your Mobile Phone to any Digital FPV setup (ADVANCED) 
1)Create a Network connection between your digital receiver and your phone 
2)On your receiver, forward rtp h264 video stream via UDP to Port 5600 and Telemetry to the equivalent Ports (5001,5001 usw) 
 or raw h264 video stream via UDP to Port 5600 when disabling parseRTP
Connect to EZ-WifiBroadcast with PW=wifibraodcast or OpenHD with PW=wifiopenhd
PLEASE READ CAREFULLY BEFORE CHANGING VALUES !

Low persistence mode slightly decreases your perceived display response time (and therefore latency) but makes your screen flickery. Disable it here if you dont like it. Only has an effect when SuperSync is enabled.
NETWORK
